channel.title: Comments on: The differences between LEN and DATALENGTH in SQL Server
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Adding a minimum length constraint in SQL Server – ichi
item.dc:creator: Adding a minimum length constraint in SQL Server – ichi
item.description: […] This might seem fairly obvious, but using Len(ColumnName) can give unexpected results, as it returns the number of characters in a string instead of the number of bytes, i.e. it trims the text before it counts the characters. More details on thatÂ here. […]
item.content:encoded: […] This might seem fairly obvious, but using Len(ColumnName) can give unexpected results, as it returns the number of characters in a string instead of the number of bytes, i.e. it trims the text before it counts the characters. More details on thatÂ here. […]

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: you would use datalength when you want to count spaces which are trimmed when using len, have to work with unicode data or have to work with text or ntext data
item.content:encoded: you would use datalength when you want to count spaces which are trimmed when using len, have to work with unicode data or have to work with text or ntext data

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.content:encoded:
Excellent post. Another difference between Len and DataLength is that Len does not work for Text and nText columns, but DataLength does.

This is important for us “poor folk” stuck with SQL 2000.
